snippet: Under a government crackdown on for-profit schools that leave students with useless credentials and punishing debt, some colleges have converted to nonprofits, in lucrative deals.
abstract: Some for-profit colleges like Keiser University in Florida have transformed themselves into nonprofit schools in wake of government crackdown on for-profit schools; Keiser is now called Everglades College, and its shift shows how owners of for-profit schools can reap benefits of state grants, federal student loan program and get tax exemptions by accepting more restrictions on moneymaking ventures and giving up ownership.
lead_paragraph: Under a government crackdown on for-profit schools that leave students with useless credentials and punishing debt, some colleges have converted to nonprofits, in lucrative deals.

headline.main: Some Owners of Private Colleges Turn a Tidy Profit by Going Nonprofit
headline.print_headline: Some Private Colleges Turn a Tidy Profit by Going Nonprofit
